item.title: [SPR-852] Cannot load Context with JDK 1.3.0, fails when try to log information.
item.description:
When Spring tries to load the context it fails using JDK 1.3.0

Here is the spring code where it fails in XmlBeanDefinitionReader,
Code:

if (logger.isInfoEnabled()) {
logger.info("Loading XML bean definitions from " + resource + "");
}

java.lang.ArrayStoreException
at java.lang.System.arraycopy(Native Method)
at java.lang.String.getChars(String.java:552)
at java.lang.StringBuffer.append(StringBuffer.java:402)
at java.lang.StringBuffer.append(StringBuffer.java:370)
at org.springframework.beans.factory.xml.XmlBeanDefinitionReader.loadBeanDefinitions(XmlBeanDefinitionReader.java:119)
at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractBeanDefinitionReader.loadBeanDefinitions(AbstractBeanDefinitionReader.java:83)
at org.springframework.context.support.AbstractXmlApplicationContext.loadBeanDefinitions(AbstractXmlApplicationContext.java:101)
at org.springframework.context.support.AbstractXmlApplicationContext.loadBeanDefinitions(AbstractXmlApplicationContext.java:69)
at org.springframework.context.support.AbstractRefreshableApplicationContext.refreshBeanFactory(AbstractRefreshableApplicationContext.java:87)
at org.springframework.context.support.AbstractApplicationContext.refresh(AbstractApplicationContext.java:262)
at org.springframework.context.support.FileSystemXmlApplicationContext.<init>(FileSystemXmlApplicationContext.java:82)
at org.springframework.context.support.FileSystemXmlApplicationContext.<init>(FileSystemXmlApplicationContext.java:67)

Example to create the simplest context:
import org.springframework.context.ApplicationContext;
import org.springframework.context.support.FileSystemXmlApplicationContext;

public class TestContext {
private static ApplicationContext ctx= null;
static String[] paths =

{"applicationContext.xml"}

;

public static void setContext() {
try

{ ctx = new FileSystemXmlApplicationContext(paths); }

catch (Exception e)

{ e.printStackTrace(); }

}
public TestContext() {}

public static void main(String args[])

{ TestContext test = new TestContext(); test.setContext(); }

}
Or Simple code which directly calls and try to log instance of "Resource"

import org.springframework.core.io.Resource;
import org.springframework.core.io.AbstractResource;
import org.springframework.core.io.ClassPathResource;
import org.apache.log4j.Logger;
import java.util.ArrayList;

public class TestContext {
public TestContext() {}

public static void main(String args[])

{ TestContext test = new TestContext(); Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(test.getClass()); ArrayList a = new ArrayList(); logger.info("Logging ArrayList To: " + a); Resource ar = new ClassPathResource("applicationContext.xml"); logger.info("Loading XML bean definitions from " + ar); }

}

javac -classpath .;lib\spring.jar;lib\commons-logging.jar;lib\xerces.jar;lib\log4j.jar TestContext.java

java -classpath .;lib\spring.jar;lib\commons-logging.jar;lib\xerces.jar;lib\log4j.jar TestContext

The example can log ArrayList object but fails when logging Resource! Didn't get a chance to look into other object's behaviour other than Resource.

Thanks,
Kunal

comments.comment:
Wow, that's pretty strange. The code seems to fail in the internal StringBuffer append calls that String concatenation gets translated to. Seems to be a Java compiler bug that me...

I don't have JDK 1.3.0 around anymore. Are you really using such an old JDK? Actually, Sun JDK 1.3.0 has already reached its end-of-life and is not even covered by Sun support anymore.

I've just verified that this works on JDK 1.3.1 for me. Could you check whether it works on JDK 1.3.1 for you too, if you haven't already? Do have any chance of upgrading to at least JDK 1.3.1?

Juergen

I know about the very old version and spring also works with me on 1.3.1 onwards. But the Spring README says, spring can work from 1.3 and onwards!

We will be using JVM 1.4+ soon, but we wanted to use spring in the current environment (1.3.0)! I thought of notifying here so that spring can either update the document or resolve this issue.

Thank you,
Kunal

I've just tried to install JDK 1.3.0 on my Windows XP machine, and the installer doesn't work - it simply disappears after the startup screen. As JDK 1.3.0 is already end-of-lifed by Sun, I guess I won't bother with trying any further.

The stacktrace that you showed looks suspiciously like a JDK bug. A further indication is that we've never heard of such an issue on any other JDK, neither Sun nor IBM nor JRockit (even including IBM JDK 1.3.0).

I'll adapt the readme accordingly: Spring is officially supported on JDK 1.3.1+; older JDK versions are neither supported by Sun nor by IBM (as far as I was able to find out).

In any case, thanks for pointing this issue out! I hope you'll be able to migrate to JDK 1.3.1 or 1.4 soon

Juergen

We are using spring 1.0 in production with JRE 1.3.0 (Silverstream 3.7.5, Sparc/SunOs 5.6) for a year now with no issue. Spring 1.1.5 is used on our development server with the same software configuration.

I've received the same exception this Wednesday while I was trying to profile our application on my workstation (nt4).

I tried to change the JRE (1.3.1_09) as Juergen suggest it but I get the same error.

After few hours spent on this issue, it seems that the problem shows up when the JRE is launched with the -classic flag as required by the profiler.

Hmm, it even works on Sun JDK 1.3.1_09 on Windows with "-classic" flag for me. Could it be that the problem only arises on Sun JDK 1.3.x on Solaris with "-classic" flag?

Juergen

It was on windows (nt4).

When I tried to launch silverstream with -classic flag, spring failed to load the application context.

It works without the flag.

Now, I don't really know what silverstream do behind the scene with jre, classloaders, etc... when this flag is set.

But AFAIK, spring works with JRE 1.3.0 on windows and solaris.

Yes, even -classic flag works with me on windows.

Great if spring is working on windows and solaris using 1.3.0. Could you please make sure that you are using version of J2SE 1.3.0 (link attached with this issue).

And if possible post the version numbers of jars that you use for your simplest spring application. e.g. xerces, spring, log4j, commons-logging.
I am going to use 1.3.1_14 soon but it will be useful to somebody who hits the same error.

Thank you,
Kunal

OK, so which versions and configurations of the JDK are known to definitely not work then? It seems that Spring does in general work on JDK 1.3.0 on both Windows and Solaris, even with the "-classic" flag... so I'm slightly confused.

Juergen

I'm still having this issue with JRE 1.3.1 with -classic flag.

That prevents us to profile our application (using jprofiler3).

I've just done a fresh install of JRE 1.3.1_15.

D:\tmp\spr-852>d:\jdk1.3.1_15\jre\bin\java -classic -showversion -classpath spring.jar;commons-logging.jar;log4j.jar;. TestContext
java version "1.3.1_15"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.3.1_15-b01)

log4j:WARN No appenders could be found for logger (TestContext).
log4j:WARN Please initialize the log4j system properly.
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.springframework.core.io.AbstractResource: method getDescription()Ljava/lang/String; not found
at java.lang.String.valueOf(String.java:2013)
at java.lang.StringBuffer.append(StringBuffer.java:365)
at TestContext.main(TestContext.java:16)

It works with JRE 1.4 and -classic flag but SilverStream can't start with JRE > 1.4.

I've finally been able to reproduce this with a minimal environment and "-classic" on JDK 1.3.1.

Fortunately, I've also been able to figure out the cause: AbstractResource's "toString" implementation delegates to the "getDescription" method as defined in the Resource interface. This doesn't seem to work with the classic VM (which has been superseded by the client VM in JDK 1.4+, where that does work properly). I've now explicitly added "getDescription" as abstract method in the AbstractResource class (just shadowing the interface method); now it works properly with "-classic" on JDK 1.3 too!

Odd circumstances... but I think it should be resolved now.

Juergen

So, the change will be available online in "Nightly Snapshot Builds" for April 13th,
spring-framework-1.2-rc2-build.243-20050413.zip

Thank you,
Kunal

Yes, it should be available in tonight's nightly build. The official 1.2 RC2 be released tomorrow, BTW, so you won't have to wait long until the fix is available in an official release!
